questions.neutral: Do the streets feel heavier today?

hobby.message: Freestyle FPV... your kind of silence, right?
Urban exploration or just avoiding work?
Is analog photography still worth the risk?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I explore the city's underground. It's a different world down there.
neutral_answer: Heavier than usual. Could be the extra checkpoints, or just everyone on edge.
Been staying off the main roads myself, keeps life simpler.
I spend my time in old tunnels—urban exploring, nothing exciting lately.
All these breakaways make even a hobby feel like a risk.
Feels tense out there, sure—more patrols, fewer folks after dark.
I do urban exploration, mostly tunnels and sealed sites—safe, or used to be.
Lately some of the best spots are just locked down, thanks to the BCI mess.
Even hobbyists like me have to dodge re-routes and watch where we step.
Free zones aren’t as free as they sound from below.
City's got a weight to it these days, no denying.
I’m a bit of a tunnel rat—urban exploring old infrastructure after hours.
Guess that's a strange hobby, but you learn to appreciate silence and rust.
The breakaway zones are shaking up my old routes—lots suddenly off limits.
Was mapping new closures last week, heard actual voices in a shut-off sector.
Never used to bump into anyone down there except the echoes.
Yeah, heavy is the word—streets, checkpoints, even the air feels tense.
I get my peace crawling old tunnels and data centers—call it urban exploring.
Lately, entrances are barricaded, and 'free zones' post their own warnings.
Last time out, I skirted one breakaway’s territory; overheard a real council meeting below.
Funny how secret places now have more people than rooftops.
Miss the days when nobody cared if you wandered.
Now, even a quiet hobby feels like trespassing on history in motion.
Definitely heavier. Used to be, after midnight was my time to breathe.
Exploring old tunnels was just escape—now it’s a dance through shifting borders.
All these free zones mean some routes are cut or heavily watched.
Last week, I found a shaft blocked, another with new graffiti—markers for who’s trusted, who’s not.
Heard laughter echoing from a council meeting below, sounded like early days.
Been charting dead zones, but also picking up stories that never make broadcasts.
Reminds me why I started—back before BCI, when silence underground meant freedom, not suspicion.
Feels like everyone’s mapping out escape routes, even the city itself.
hobby_answer: Not really. Still keeps me busy most nights.
City’s changing though. Harder to find quiet routes.
Some places are off-limits now with these free zones.
Security’s heavier too. Less time to linger.
Got to keep my head down. That’s enough.
Never boring, too much to see down there.
These breakaway zones make it trickier—entrances getting blocked.
Avoiding places flagged on broadcasts nowadays.
Whole city feels tighter; even my old routes are getting risky.
Ran into extra patrols last week. Not worth trouble some nights.
Still, nothing else clears my head like it.
Doesn’t get boring. Cities never sit still.
Was out near Korolsk after one of those zone cutoffs.
Whole tunnel section was sealed, new signs everywhere.
Had to backtrack, found another way in by the substation.
Heard real voices, not sensors, coming from the breakaway side.
People running their own thing. Sounded lively, if tense.
Feels different—like the city’s shifting underfoot again.
Never bored—something happens every crawl, even now.
Past few weeks, mapping’s half guessing. Free zones popping up overnight.
Had to give up on a tunnel I’ve used for years, thanks to barricades.
Ran into a group patching their own lights, no uniforms anywhere.
Reminded me of old times, before everything was monitored.
Saw hand-made notices, not system warnings—strange feeling.
Makes you wonder who’s really tracking who.
Still, I keep my logs tight. City’s eyes everywhere, even when they’re blind.
Not a chance. I live for it, honestly.
Used to know every access panel between here and the river—now it’s a dice roll nightly.
These new free zones? Saw firsthand how fast they claim utility tunnels.
Got cornered last week by locals—thought I was with compliance patrol.
Had to trade a battery pack to avoid an argument.
Funny—I remember when nobody cared you slipped through the dark. Now everybody’s watching the watchers.
Last Tuesday, nearly stumbled into an underground assembly meeting—felt like old union cell days.
Took notes, but I’ll never report those. They’re just trying to carve space of their own.
Guess the system’s stretched. You see the cracks up close, hobby or not.
